title: Is it grammatically correct to say, 'a pair of twins'? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a tricky question. As another Quoran has indicated, a pair of twins could mean two sets of twins. That’s certainly a reasonable read of the phrase - and a reasonable usage. However, things mean what they mean, not what we impute to them. Some languages have something called a “classifier.” It’s a word that indicates “what type” of thing we’re talking about, or gives details about it. Here’s a good article about one language - Mandarin Chinese’s - use of classifiers: 5 ridiculously specific Chinese classifiers – ChineseMe English seems to use a few classifiers, a bit. My favorite example is “couple.” Here’s a typical use of the word as an informal classifier in the dialect of English I speak: [At the home improvement store] I’m just after a couple two or three options. By the same token, though in the past “couple” might have meant literally two - and still can be used that way - nowadays it means “an amount less than a few,” the phrase “a few” also having fuzzy boundaries. So, it we look again at the phrase originally cited - "a pair of twins" - and see the word “pair” more as a classifier than a quantifier, then the phrase is both correct and correct when only referring to two babies.

Yes, it is correct. John is a twin. His twin brother is James. You could just say 'they are twins'. Mary is a twin. Her twin sister is Margaret. You could just say 'they are twins'. All four children are twins, but there are two pairs of twins. One pair of twins are boys and the other pair of twins are girls.
